<!-- slide -->

## Week 6 Lesson 1

<!-- slide -->

## Looking back

1. HTML Basics ✅
2. CSS Basics ✅
3. File structure of a static site ✅
4. Source Control ✅
5. JavaScript Fundamentals ✅

<!-- slide -->

### Looking forward

You may say

> OK, now I can create a HTML page with some CSS for styling and JavaScript for interactivity.
>
> But how do I apply my programming skills in my job besides creating a simple website?
>
> And btw, I found data structure kind of useless...

<!-- slide vertical -->

Answer

> Besides being able to create things like programs/websites,
>
> **programmatic thinking** is what we want you to take away from this course instead of things like specific syntax of JavaScript or CSS

<!-- slide vertical -->

> To get you good at solving problems,
>
> we will look at some language independent problems

<!-- slide -->

## This lesson

- Consolidating problem solving skills
  - Resistor Color
  - Two Sum

<!-- slide -->

### Resistor Color

Resistors have color coded bands, where each color maps to a number. The first 2 bands of a resistor have a simple encoding scheme: each color maps to a single number.

<!-- slide vertical -->

These colors are encoded as follows:

Black: 0
Brown: 1
Red: 2
Orange: 3
Yellow: 4
Green: 5
Blue: 6
Violet: 7
Grey: 8
White: 9

[Read more about it](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_color_code)

<!-- slide vertical -->

#### Problem

Given a color, return the coresponding number.

Example:

```js
-> colorCode('black')
0
-> colorCode('white')
9
```

<!-- slide -->

### Two Sum

Given an array of integers, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to a specific target.

You may assume that each input would have exactly **one solution**, and you may not use the same element twice.

<!-- slide vertical -->

### Example

```
Given nums = [2, 7, 11, 15], target = 9,

Because nums[0] + nums[1] = 2 + 7 = 9,
return [0, 1].
```
